explanation:
For each listed symbol the analyzer must see the actual declaration/definition to determine if any compiler-specific language extensions are used (which would violate the MISRA rule). Brief reasons: 
- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET: macro — macros commonly hide GCC/clang extensions (statement-expr, typeof, __extension__, nested macros); inspect definition. 
- OS_impl_filehandle_table: table declaration could use compiler attributes or nonstandard section/visibility extensions. 
- OS_impl_file_internal_record_t: struct definition may contain anonymous/unnamed structs/unions, bit-field widths, or other extensions. 
- OS_object_token_t: type alias could be implemented with nonstandard attributes or typedefs using extensions. 
- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken: related helper function/macro used by OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET; its signature/definition may use extensions. 
- OS_SockAddr_t: application socket wrapper type — definition needed to check for anonymous unions/structs or other extensions and to verify AddrData layout. 
- RemoteAddr->AddrData: member referenced and casted; its type/layout could rely on extensions (e.g., flexible array, anonymous members). 
- RemoteAddr->ActualLength: member written — definition needed to confirm standard-compliant declaration. 
- OS_SOCKADDR_MAX_LEN: constant/macro — macro could be defined with extensions. 
- OS_STREAM_STATE_READABLE: constant/enum/macro — definition might use nonstandard constructs. 
- OS_SelectSingle_Impl: callee — function prototype may use attributes (format, noreturn) or nonstandard calling conventions. 
- OS_SUCCESS: return-code macro/enum — check definition for nonstandard constructs. 
- MSG_DONTWAIT: socket flag from system headers — ensure header uses standard constructs (or platform extension). 
- recvfrom: system call wrapper — prototype/headers may use platform-specific extensions; presence of glibc or POSIX headers should be checked. 
- errno: macro/object — its definition can be a macro returning thread-local or function call; check for compiler-specific TLS extensions. 
- EAGAIN / EWOULDBLOCK: errno macros — their definitions may be macros or enums; check headers for nonstandard use. 
- OS_QUEUE_EMPTY: error-code macro/enum — inspect for extension usage. 
- OS_DEBUG: logging macro — often implemented with variadic macros or attributes (format) or GCC-specific extensions; inspect definition. 
- strerror: standard library function — check prototype/headers for extensions. 
- OS_ERROR: error-code macro/enum — inspect definition. 
- struct sockaddr: standard type — include to check for any platform-specific redefinitions or nonstandard extensions. 
- socklen_t: typedef — platform typedef may use nonstandard attributes. 
- size_t: standard typedef — check header in build environment for extensions. 
- int32 / uint32: project typedefs (likely fixed-width) — definitions may use compiler-specific attributes or builtins. 

In short: examine these symbols' declarations/definitions (macros, typedefs, structs, function prototypes) because compiler extensions are most likely hidden there rather than in the straightforward C statements inside the function body.
